issue.title: depict 1H-imidazole
issue.body:
Am trying to highlight an imidazole fragment on a parent compound. Tried a number of variations on the 
imidazole SMILES without success. Past github requests of this issue have disappeared??
Following code will not highlight imidazole? Can anyone help??

> tmp_smi
[1] "CC(n1c(C)ncc1c1ccnc(n1)Nc1ccc(cc1)S(=O)(=O)C)C"
> tmp_label
[1] "CMGC:CDC2:6gu3:A:FB8"
   pen <- parse_smiles(paste(tmp_smi, tmp_label,sep=" "))
   atms <- pen$atoms()
   bnds <- pen$bonds()
   tmp_frag <- 'c1cnc[nH]1'  #1H-imidazole
   cav <- parse.smiles(tmp_frag)
   lactam <- match_smarts(tmp_frag, pen)
      depiction() %>%
             highlight_atoms(atms, color$LIGHT_GRAY) %>%
             highlight_atoms(bnds, color$LIGHT_GRAY) %>%
             highlight_atoms(lactam, color$GREEN) %>%
             set_size(1400, 1400) %>%
             set_zoom(4) %>%
             outerglow() %>%
#             add_title() %>%
             depict(pen) %>%
             get_image() %>%
             grid::grid.raster()

How are you accessing this? I don’t provide any of those API points.

Mainly curious.

The web API (I have not idea what api you are using) expects a SMARTS and not a SMILES. There is a subtle difference but you’ve queried for a nitrogen with a hydrogen attached but there are none.

“c1ncnc1”
Or
“c1nc[nX3]c1”

pull_request.title: Reaction arrows
pull_request.body:
Some extra pieces related to arrow styles. We had a lesser known mechanism for putting reaction conditions below and arrow (e.g. "Heat 2h"). We use the same mechanism for specifying the reaction arrow.

```
[CH3:9][CH:8]([CH3:10])[c:7]1[cH:11][cH:12][cH:13][cH:14][cH:15]1.[CH2:3]([CH2:4][C:5](=[O:6])Cl)[CH2:2][Cl:1]>[Al+3].[Cl-].[Cl-].[Cl-].C(Cl)Cl>[CH3:9][CH:8]([CH3:10])[c:7]1[cH:11][cH:12][c:13]([cH:14][cH:15]1)[C:5](=[O:6])[CH2:4][CH2:3][CH2:2][Cl:1] |SgD::cdk.Arrow:NGO|
```

comment.body:
Hi Ronan,

I'm only partially involved in this project but answer questions when I can. I am however the developer for CDK so this is an easy one. Maven SNAPSHOT dependencies are mainly for "development" and really this should be v2.5 or (v2.8.1 is the latest).

Either use the release build (GitHubside bar).

Or if building you should be able to fix it by changing the dependency of CDK to v2.5.

```
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.openscience.cdk</groupId>
            <artifactId>cdk-bundle</artifactId>
            <version>2.4-SNAPSHOT</version>
        </dependency>
```

```
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.openscience.cdk</groupId>
            <artifactId>cdk-bundle</artifactId>
            <version>2.5</version>
        </dependency>
```

**2.8.1** may also work but APIs might have changed subtlety.

issue.title: thoughts about input of .sdf (version 3000) / extended stereochemistry
issue.body:
This spurs off of a discussion [here](https://github.com/cdk/depict/issues/52) and a contribution by @adafede about atom numbering.  At present, the program allows input as SMILES, or copy-paste of .sdf.  If present and requested, it can can assign and label stereochemistry, too.

Venturing out a couple of variations about and around tartaric acid sketched in [DataWarrior](https://openmolecules.org/datawarrior/index.html) (repository [on GitHub](https://github.com/thsa/datawarrior)), I noticed CDKdepict does not process DataWarrior's structures exported in the more recent V3000 dialect of .sdf.  Extending the more senior format, this allows to store and process extended stereochemistry as in `&` and `or` for a stereogenic centre:

![entry_05](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19709084/197986727-97e5980f-096c-4f24-89c5-1a85949f2e92.png)

Do you think the additional file format and its extended functionality would be worth the effort to be implemented into future versions of CDKDepict?

[2022-10-26_stereochemistry_variations.zip](https://github.com/cdk/depict/files/9868014/2022-10-26_stereochemistry_variations.zip)

comment.body:
Fixed, will need to shift reload the webpage as the JS needed updating.

Note in SMILES/depict "ABS" is default and not displayed (same as chiral flag=1), if you set chiral_flag=0 will see the different. 

Anyways on your examples it's really on the last two where you see it.

![Screenshot 2022-10-26 at 13 05 04](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/983232/198021632-7f736069-7171-49fc-9cd9-b5fbaf712b05.png)

issue.title: thoughts about input of .sdf (version 3000) / extended stereochemistry
issue.body:
This spurs off of a discussion [here](https://github.com/cdk/depict/issues/52) and a contribution by @adafede about atom numbering.  At present, the program allows input as SMILES, or copy-paste of .sdf.  If present and requested, it can can assign and label stereochemistry, too.

Venturing out a couple of variations about and around tartaric acid sketched in [DataWarrior](https://openmolecules.org/datawarrior/index.html) (repository [on GitHub](https://github.com/thsa/datawarrior)), I noticed CDKdepict does not process DataWarrior's structures exported in the more recent V3000 dialect of .sdf.  Extending the more senior format, this allows to store and process extended stereochemistry as in `&` and `or` for a stereogenic centre:

![entry_05](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19709084/197986727-97e5980f-096c-4f24-89c5-1a85949f2e92.png)

Do you think the additional file format and its extended functionality would be worth the effort to be implemented into future versions of CDKDepict?

[2022-10-26_stereochemistry_variations.zip](https://github.com/cdk/depict/files/9868014/2022-10-26_stereochemistry_variations.zip)

comment.body:
Depict is primarily for SMILES input and this is possible with the CXSMILES extensions. Try these out.

```
OC(=O)[C@H](O)[C@H](O)C(=O)O |&1:3|
OC(=O)[C@H](O)[C@H](O)C(=O)O |o1:3|
OC(=O)[C@H](O)[C@H](O)C(=O)O |&1:3,5|
OC(=O)[C@H](O)[C@H](O)C(=O)O |o1:3,5|
```

I really don't like allow MOLfile and I think the key issue here is we only expect V2000, so in practise it's a simple fix.

issue.title: @(bond in ring), !@ (bond not in ring) and @;!:(ring but non-aromatic) bond expression
issue.body:
Dear Developers,

I am using the SmartsPattern feature with Daylight SMARTS. It seems that @ expression can work in bond in ring match properly. However, !@ and @;!: don't work as expected and return true for any bond types.
Is cdk2.8 able to handle these bond expressions as described in Daylight SMARTS? If so, could you please show me some guidance? If not, are there any possible solutions? Currently, I am using R/r or !R/r with atoms as an alternative approach but it would be much better and easier if the bond notation can work.

Thank you.

comment.body: We have different models of aromaticity to pick and choose as you see fit. By default for SMARTS we apply Daylight aromaticity (since SMARTS was created by Daylight). However it is possible to use a different aromaticity model.

issue.body:
Dear Developers,

I am using the SmartsPattern feature with Daylight SMARTS. It seems that @ expression can work in bond in ring match properly. However, !@ and @;!: don't work as expected and return true for any bond types.
Is cdk2.8 able to handle these bond expressions as described in Daylight SMARTS? If so, could you please show me some guidance? If not, are there any possible solutions? Currently, I am using R/r or !R/r with atoms as an alternative approach but it would be much better and easier if the bond notation can work.

comment.body:
Depict is not for depiction queries (SMARTS). You put molecules (SMILES) in the top and SMARTS in the "Enter SMARTS pattern..." where you want to match.

```
SMILES: c1cccnc1-N1CC=CC=C1
SMARTS: **[#6]~1[#6]~[#6][#6](=,:[#7][#6]~1)!@-[#7]-1-[#6]-[#6]=[#6]-[#6]=[#6]-1
```

Works correctly for me.

issue.title: NPE in getInChIToStructure for radioactive elements
issue.body:
The following line throws a NullPointerException for radioactive elements like Technetium-99:
https://github.com/cdk/cdk/blob/cdk-2.8/storage/inchi/src/main/java/org/openscience/cdk/inchi/InChIToStructure.java#L195

Seems like this corresponds to `getMajorIsotope` returning null.

For example:
```java
InChIGeneratorFactory.getInstance().getInChIToStructure(
    "InChI=1S/Tc/i1+1",
    DefaultChemObjectBuilder.getInstance(),
).getAtomContainer()
```

I think the desired behavior would be to either (a) translate the NPE into a more informative CDKException, or (b) if possible, avoid the NPE altogether and continue generating the atom container.

comment.body:
Thanks. 

The correct fix here is we should use the inchi isotope table. The +1 mass delta is from an arbitrary table and not the major isotope. This is inherited from the molfile which also did it this way.

See slide 4 here: https://www.nextmovesoftware.com/talks/Mayfield_BuildingOnSand_InChI_201708.pdf

this is one of the many reasons trying to turn an inchi back into a molecule is not a good idea.

issue.title: SmartsPattern can't apply regex for rings.
issue.body:
Dear developers,
Thank you for developing such a great library.
I met some problems when I use the SmartsPattern feature with daylight SMARTS.
SMARTS: [#6]-[C;!R](-[O;!R])=[O;X1] where [C;!R] means a carbon atom that is not in a ring.
When I run the matches function in the SmartsPattern feature for molecule with SMILES="O=C1COC(=O)C1=CC1=CC=CC=C1", it returns true. However, it should return false since the SMARTS specifies that the pattern should not be in a ring.
Could you please let me know if I didn't use it properly, or if there is any existing approaches to do the same work?
Thanks

Thank you for developing such a great library.

SMARTS: [#6]-[C;!R](-[O;!R])=[O;X1] where [C;!R] means a carbon atom that is not in a ring.
When I run the matches function in the SmartsPattern feature for molecule with SMILES="O=C1COC(=O)C1=CC1=CC=CC=C1", it returns true. However, it should return false since the SMARTS specifies that the pattern should not be in a ring.

comment.body:
> where [C;!R] means a carbon atom that is not in a ring

**aliphatic** carbon atom not in a ring.

SetPrepare should be on by default. Turning this off says “I know what I’m doing”.

If you want to mark rings flags manually you can do that. Prepare will also aromaticity.

A common use case to turn this off is matching multiple patterns against a single molecule. You may have already set the ring flags for another reason - maybe your extracted a murko scaffold. Anyways there are reasons to give this level of control and the default should do the right thing.

issue.title: Bulk data server stopped accepting byte ranges
issue.body:
Recently the USPTO bulk data server stopped accepting byte range requests. This feature was convenient because it was possible to download just a single patent (and associated data) taking much less space/bandwidth.

Example:

```
curl -v -r 75428323-75548735 https://bulkdata.uspto.gov/data/patent/application/redbook/2022/I20220908.tar -output US20220281887A1.zip
```

The server sends by HTTP status 200 (instead of 206), reports it accepts ranges then sends back **5GB** instead of **120KB**.

```
< HTTP/1.1 200 OK
< Accept-Ranges: bytes
< Content-Length: 5245327360
```

The Google mirror <2015 shows how this is meant to work:

```
curl -v -r 1065965668-1065996692 http://storage.googleapis.com/patents/redbook/applications/2007/I20070607.ZIP -o US2007129372_output
```

```
< HTTP/1.1 206 Partial Content
...
< Accept-Ranges: bytes
< Content-Range: bytes 1065965668-1065996692/1358212086
< Content-Length: 31025
```

Hoping someone on the technical side at USPTO knows what has happened, be it a server upgrade/reconfiguration etc?

John

issue.title: Add transform/SMIRKS support to CDK.

comment.body:
> Hi guys! Please advise what do you think about Java Stream API usage in CDK? And what is the general policy about Java versions (for ex. support of 7 comes to the end https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/java-se-support-roadmap.html)? Thanks in advance!
> 
> Suggestions (and for min as well):
> 
> ```
> int max = 0;
> for (TransformOp op : ops)
>   max = Math.max(op.getMaxAtomIdx(), max);
> return max;
> ```
> 
> Could be expressed as:
> 
> ```
> return ops.stream().mapToInt(TransformOp::getMaxAtomIdx).max().orElse(0);
> ```
> 
> Also, seen declarations of `Iterable<IAtomContainer>`, etc. which return mutable lists. Suggestion:
> 
> ```
> return Collections.unmodifiableList(list)
> ```

We are on Java 8 not 7. See other discussions, will likely move to 17 for CDK 3.0.
I like the stream API where it improves readability and performance. I don’t think the usage here is clearer than the for loop though.

the intention with their iterator is we can lazily apply the transforms (like we do for substructure matches) for now it is simpler to just return the list but yes I will try and remember to make it immutable.

issue.title: NPE in CDKAtomTypeMatcher
issue.body:
I opened PR #919 that adds a `@Disabled` test to `CDKAtomTypeMatcherFilesTest`.

Irrespective of the meaningfulness of the chemical structure of the added file `dativeBond.sdf` the `CDKAtomTypeMatcher` throws a `NPE` with that structure due to `IBond.getOrder` being `null` when calling `QueryAtomContainer.getMaximumBondOrder`.

I don't have a concrete idea what should happen in this case, but throwing an NPE is probably not the best outcome... 🤷🏼

comment.body:
See my comment on that PR, unfortunately it's a case of garbage in garbage out... but a better error is "query bond not allowed here or similar".

Since calling the CDKAtomTypeMatcher is optional (and sometimes wrong[1]) this is a tricky one. 

1. the MOL file readers put the correct Hydrogen count using the MDL/Symyx valence model. Applying the CDK model on top of this can change what was provided.

Note V3000 has bond type 9 and 10 for dative and hbonds and this is much more portable.

comment.body:
Hi Ronan,

I'm only partially involved in this project but answer questions when I can. I am however the developer for CDK so this is an easy one. Maven SNAPSHOT dependencies are mainly for "development" and really this should be v2.5 or (v2.8.1 is the latest).

Either use the release build (GitHubside bar).

Or if building you should be able to fix it by changing the dependency of CDK to v2.5.

```

            <artifactId>cdk-bundle</artifactId>
            <version>2.4-SNAPSHOT</version>

            <artifactId>cdk-bundle</artifactId>
            <version>2.5</version>
        </dependency>
```

issue.title: thoughts about input of .sdf (version 3000) / extended stereochemistry
issue.body:
This spurs off of a discussion [here](https://github.com/cdk/depict/issues/52) and a contribution by @adafede about atom numbering.  At present, the program allows input as SMILES, or copy-paste of .sdf.  If present and requested, it can can assign and label stereochemistry, too.

Venturing out a couple of variations about and around tartaric acid sketched in [DataWarrior](https://openmolecules.org/datawarrior/index.html) (repository [on GitHub](https://github.com/thsa/datawarrior)), I noticed CDKdepict does not process DataWarrior's structures exported in the more recent V3000 dialect of .sdf.  Extending the more senior format, this allows to store and process extended stereochemistry as in `&` and `or` for a stereogenic centre:

![entry_05](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19709084/197986727-97e5980f-096c-4f24-89c5-1a85949f2e92.png)

Do you think the additional file format and its extended functionality would be worth the effort to be implemented into future versions of CDKDepict?

[2022-10-26_stereochemistry_variations.zip](https://github.com/cdk/depict/files/9868014/2022-10-26_stereochemistry_variations.zip)

Depict is primarily for SMILES input and this is possible with the CXSMILES extensions. Try these out.

```
OC(=O)[C@H](O)[C@H](O)C(=O)O |&1:3|
OC(=O)[C@H](O)[C@H](O)C(=O)O |o1:3|

comment.body:
Depict is not for depiction queries (SMARTS). You put molecules (SMILES) in the top and SMARTS in the "Enter SMARTS pattern..." where you want to match.

```
SMILES: c1cccnc1-N1CC=CC=C1
SMARTS: **[#6]~1[#6]~[#6][#6](=,:[#7][#6]~1)!@-[#7]-1-[#6]-[#6]=[#6]-[#6]=[#6]-1
```

Works correctly for me.

issue.title: NPE in getInChIToStructure for radioactive elements
issue.body:
The following line throws a NullPointerException for radioactive elements like Technetium-99:
https://github.com/cdk/cdk/blob/cdk-2.8/storage/inchi/src/main/java/org/openscience/cdk/inchi/InChIToStructure.java#L195

Seems like this corresponds to `getMajorIsotope` returning null.

For example:
```java
InChIGeneratorFactory.getInstance().getInChIToStructure(
    "InChI=1S/Tc/i1+1",
    DefaultChemObjectBuilder.getInstance(),
).getAtomContainer()
```

I think the desired behavior would be to either (a) translate the NPE into a more informative CDKException, or (b) if possible, avoid the NPE altogether and continue generating the atom container.

comment.body:
Thanks. 

The correct fix here is we should use the inchi isotope table. The +1 mass delta is from an arbitrary table and not the major isotope. This is inherited from the molfile which also did it this way.

See slide 4 here: https://www.nextmovesoftware.com/talks/Mayfield_BuildingOnSand_InChI_201708.pdf

this is one of the many reasons trying to turn an inchi back into a molecule is not a good idea.

issue.title: SmartsPattern can't apply regex for rings.
issue.body:
Dear developers,
Thank you for developing such a great library.
I met some problems when I use the SmartsPattern feature with daylight SMARTS.
SMARTS: [#6]-[C;!R](-[O;!R])=[O;X1] where [C;!R] means a carbon atom that is not in a ring.
When I run the matches function in the SmartsPattern feature for molecule with SMILES="O=C1COC(=O)C1=CC1=CC=CC=C1", it returns true. However, it should return false since the SMARTS specifies that the pattern should not be in a ring.
Could you please let me know if I didn't use it properly, or if there is any existing approaches to do the same work?
Thanks

comment.body:
> where [C;!R] means a carbon atom that is not in a ring

**aliphatic** carbon atom not in a ring.

SetPrepare should be on by default. Turning this off says “I know what I’m doing”.

If you want to mark rings flags manually you can do that. Prepare will also aromaticity.

A common use case to turn this off is matching multiple patterns against a single molecule. You may have already set the ring flags for another reason - maybe your extracted a murko scaffold. Anyways there are reasons to give this level of control and the default should do the right thing.

issue.title: Bulk data server stopped accepting byte ranges
issue.body:
Recently the USPTO bulk data server stopped accepting byte range requests. This feature was convenient because it was possible to download just a single patent (and associated data) taking much less space/bandwidth.

Example:

```
curl -v -r 75428323-75548735 https://bulkdata.uspto.gov/data/patent/application/redbook/2022/I20220908.tar -output US20220281887A1.zip
```

The server sends by HTTP status 200 (instead of 206), reports it accepts ranges then sends back **5GB** instead of **120KB**.

```
< HTTP/1.1 200 OK
< Accept-Ranges: bytes
< Content-Length: 5245327360
```

The Google mirror <2015 shows how this is meant to work:

```
curl -v -r 1065965668-1065996692 http://storage.googleapis.com/patents/redbook/applications/2007/I20070607.ZIP -o US2007129372_output
```

```
< HTTP/1.1 206 Partial Content
...
< Accept-Ranges: bytes
< Content-Range: bytes 1065965668-1065996692/1358212086
< Content-Length: 31025
```

Hoping someone on the technical side at USPTO knows what has happened, be it a server upgrade/reconfiguration etc?

John

issue.title: Bulk data server stopped accepting byte ranges
issue.body:
Recently the USPTO bulk data server stopped accepting byte range requests. This feature was convenient because it was possible to download just a single patent (and associated data) taking much less space/bandwidth.

Example:

```
curl -v -r 75428323-75548735 https://bulkdata.uspto.gov/data/patent/application/redbook/2022/I20220908.tar -output US20220281887A1.zip
```

The server sends by HTTP status 200 (instead of 206), reports it accepts ranges then sends back **5GB** instead of **120KB**.

```
< HTTP/1.1 200 OK
< Accept-Ranges: bytes
< Content-Length: 5245327360
```

The Google mirror <2015 shows how this is meant to work:

```
curl -v -r 1065965668-1065996692 http://storage.googleapis.com/patents/redbook/applications/2007/I20070607.ZIP -o US2007129372_output
```

```
< HTTP/1.1 206 Partial Content
...
< Accept-Ranges: bytes
< Content-Range: bytes 1065965668-1065996692/1358212086
< Content-Length: 31025
```

Hoping someone on the technical side at USPTO knows what has happened, be it a server upgrade/reconfiguration etc?

John

comment.body:
> Hi guys! Please advise what do you think about Java Stream API usage in CDK? And what is the general policy about Java versions (for ex. support of 7 comes to the end https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/java-se-support-roadmap.html)? Thanks in advance!
> 
> Suggestions (and for min as well):
> 
> ```
> int max = 0;
> for (TransformOp op : ops)
>   max = Math.max(op.getMaxAtomIdx(), max);
> return max;
> ```
> 
> Could be expressed as:
> 
> ```
> return ops.stream().mapToInt(TransformOp::getMaxAtomIdx).max().orElse(0);
> ```
> 
> Also, seen declarations of `Iterable<IAtomContainer>`, etc. which return mutable lists. Suggestion:
> 
> ```
> return Collections.unmodifiableList(list)
> ```

We are on Java 8 not 7. See other discussions, will likely move to 17 for CDK 3.0.
I like the stream API where it improves readability and performance. I don’t think the usage here is clearer than the for loop though.

the intention with their iterator is we can lazily apply the transforms (like we do for substructure matches) for now it is simpler to just return the list but yes I will try and remember to make it immutable.

issue.title: NPE in CDKAtomTypeMatcher
issue.body:
I opened PR #919 that adds a `@Disabled` test to `CDKAtomTypeMatcherFilesTest`.

Irrespective of the meaningfulness of the chemical structure of the added file `dativeBond.sdf` the `CDKAtomTypeMatcher` throws a `NPE` with that structure due to `IBond.getOrder` being `null` when calling `QueryAtomContainer.getMaximumBondOrder`.

I don't have a concrete idea what should happen in this case, but throwing an NPE is probably not the best outcome... 🤷🏼

comment.body:
See my comment on that PR, unfortunately it's a case of garbage in garbage out... but a better error is "query bond not allowed here or similar".

Since calling the CDKAtomTypeMatcher is optional (and sometimes wrong[1]) this is a tricky one. 

1. the MOL file readers put the correct Hydrogen count using the MDL/Symyx valence model. Applying the CDK model on top of this can change what was provided.

comment.body:
Hi Ronan,

I'm only partially involved in this project but answer questions when I can. I am however the developer for CDK so this is an easy one. Maven SNAPSHOT dependencies are mainly for "development" and really this should be v2.5 or (v2.8.1 is the latest).

Either use the release build (GitHubside bar).

Or if building you should be able to fix it by changing the dependency of CDK to v2.5.

```
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.openscience.cdk</groupId>
            <artifactId>cdk-bundle</artifactId>
            <version>2.4-SNAPSHOT</version>
        </dependency>
```

```
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.openscience.cdk</groupId>
            <artifactId>cdk-bundle</artifactId>
            <version>2.5</version>
        </dependency>
```

**2.8.1** may also work but APIs might have changed subtlety.

issue.title: thoughts about input of .sdf (version 3000) / extended stereochemistry
issue.body:
This spurs off of a discussion [here](https://github.com/cdk/depict/issues/52) and a contribution by @adafede about atom numbering.  At present, the program allows input as SMILES, or copy-paste of .sdf.  If present and requested, it can can assign and label stereochemistry, too.

Venturing out a couple of variations about and around tartaric acid sketched in [DataWarrior](https://openmolecules.org/datawarrior/index.html) (repository [on GitHub](https://github.com/thsa/datawarrior)), I noticed CDKdepict does not process DataWarrior's structures exported in the more recent V3000 dialect of .sdf.  Extending the more senior format, this allows to store and process extended stereochemistry as in `&` and `or` for a stereogenic centre:

![entry_05](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19709084/197986727-97e5980f-096c-4f24-89c5-1a85949f2e92.png)

Do you think the additional file format and its extended functionality would be worth the effort to be implemented into future versions of CDKDepict?

[2022-10-26_stereochemistry_variations.zip](https://github.com/cdk/depict/files/9868014/2022-10-26_stereochemistry_variations.zip)

issue.body:
This spurs off of a discussion [here](https://github.com/cdk/depict/issues/52) and a contribution by @adafede about atom numbering.  At present, the program allows input as SMILES, or copy-paste of .sdf.  If present and requested, it can can assign and label stereochemistry, too.

Venturing out a couple of variations about and around tartaric acid sketched in [DataWarrior](https://openmolecules.org/datawarrior/index.html) (repository [on GitHub](https://github.com/thsa/datawarrior)), I noticed CDKdepict does not process DataWarrior's structures exported in the more recent V3000 dialect of .sdf.  Extending the more senior format, this allows to store and process extended stereochemistry as in `&` and `or` for a stereogenic centre:

![entry_05](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19709084/197986727-97e5980f-096c-4f24-89c5-1a85949f2e92.png)

Do you think the additional file format and its extended functionality would be worth the effort to be implemented into future versions of CDKDepict?

[2022-10-26_stereochemistry_variations.zip](https://github.com/cdk/depict/files/9868014/2022-10-26_stereochemistry_variations.zip)

comment.body:
Depict is primarily for SMILES input and this is possible with the CXSMILES extensions. Try these out.

```
OC(=O)[C@H](O)[C@H](O)C(=O)O |&1:3|
OC(=O)[C@H](O)[C@H](O)C(=O)O |o1:3|
OC(=O)[C@H](O)[C@H](O)C(=O)O |&1:3,5|
OC(=O)[C@H](O)[C@H](O)C(=O)O |o1:3,5|
```

I really don't like allow MOLfile and I think the key issue here is we only expect V2000, so in practise it's a simple fix.

issue.title: NPE in getInChIToStructure for radioactive elements
issue.body:
The following line throws a NullPointerException for radioactive elements like Technetium-99:
https://github.com/cdk/cdk/blob/cdk-2.8/storage/inchi/src/main/java/org/openscience/cdk/inchi/InChIToStructure.java#L195

Seems like this corresponds to `getMajorIsotope` returning null.

For example:
```java
InChIGeneratorFactory.getInstance().getInChIToStructure(
    "InChI=1S/Tc/i1+1",
    DefaultChemObjectBuilder.getInstance(),
).getAtomContainer()
```

I think the desired behavior would be to either (a) translate the NPE into a more informative CDKException, or (b) if possible, avoid the NPE altogether and continue generating the atom container.

comment.body:
Thanks. 

The correct fix here is we should use the inchi isotope table. The +1 mass delta is from an arbitrary table and not the major isotope. This is inherited from the molfile which also did it this way.

See slide 4 here: https://www.nextmovesoftware.com/talks/Mayfield_BuildingOnSand_InChI_201708.pdf

this is one of the many reasons trying to turn an inchi back into a molecule is not a good idea.

issue.title: SmartsPattern can't apply regex for rings.
issue.body:
Dear developers,
Thank you for developing such a great library.
I met some problems when I use the SmartsPattern feature with daylight SMARTS.
SMARTS: [#6]-[C;!R](-[O;!R])=[O;X1] where [C;!R] means a carbon atom that is not in a ring.
When I run the matches function in the SmartsPattern feature for molecule with SMILES="O=C1COC(=O)C1=CC1=CC=CC=C1", it returns true. However, it should return false since the SMARTS specifies that the pattern should not be in a ring.
Could you please let me know if I didn't use it properly, or if there is any existing approaches to do the same work?
Thanks

comment.body:
> where [C;!R] means a carbon atom that is not in a ring

**aliphatic** carbon atom not in a ring.

SetPrepare should be on by default. Turning this off says “I know what I’m doing”.

If you want to mark rings flags manually you can do that. Prepare will also aromaticity.

A common use case to turn this off is matching multiple patterns against a single molecule. You may have already set the ring flags for another reason - maybe your extracted a murko scaffold. Anyways there are reasons to give this level of control and the default should do the right thing.

issue.title: Bulk data server stopped accepting byte ranges
issue.body:
Recently the USPTO bulk data server stopped accepting byte range requests. This feature was convenient because it was possible to download just a single patent (and associated data) taking much less space/bandwidth.

Example:

```
curl -v -r 75428323-75548735 https://bulkdata.uspto.gov/data/patent/application/redbook/2022/I20220908.tar -output US20220281887A1.zip
```

The server sends by HTTP status 200 (instead of 206), reports it accepts ranges then sends back **5GB** instead of **120KB**.

```
< HTTP/1.1 200 OK
< Accept-Ranges: bytes
< Content-Length: 5245327360
```

The Google mirror <2015 shows how this is meant to work:

```
curl -v -r 1065965668-1065996692 http://storage.googleapis.com/patents/redbook/applications/2007/I20070607.ZIP -o US2007129372_output
```

```
< HTTP/1.1 206 Partial Content
...
< Accept-Ranges: bytes
< Content-Range: bytes 1065965668-1065996692/1358212086
< Content-Length: 31025
```

Hoping someone on the technical side at USPTO knows what has happened, be it a server upgrade/reconfiguration etc?

John

issue.title: Add transform/SMIRKS support to CDK.

comment.body:
> Hi guys! Please advise what do you think about Java Stream API usage in CDK? And what is the general policy about Java versions (for ex. support of 7 comes to the end https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/java-se-support-roadmap.html)? Thanks in advance!
> 
> Suggestions (and for min as well):
> 
> ```
> int max = 0;
> for (TransformOp op : ops)
>   max = Math.max(op.getMaxAtomIdx(), max);
> return max;
> ```
> 
> Could be expressed as:
> 
> ```
> return ops.stream().mapToInt(TransformOp::getMaxAtomIdx).max().orElse(0);
> ```
> 
> Also, seen declarations of `Iterable<IAtomContainer>`, etc. which return mutable lists. Suggestion:
> 
> ```
> return Collections.unmodifiableList(list)
> ```

We are on Java 8 not 7. See other discussions, will likely move to 17 for CDK 3.0.
I like the stream API where it improves readability and performance. I don’t think the usage here is clearer than the for loop though.

the intention with their iterator is we can lazily apply the transforms (like we do for substructure matches) for now it is simpler to just return the list but yes I will try and remember to make it immutable.

issue.title: NPE in CDKAtomTypeMatcher
issue.body:
I opened PR #919 that adds a `@Disabled` test to `CDKAtomTypeMatcherFilesTest`.

Irrespective of the meaningfulness of the chemical structure of the added file `dativeBond.sdf` the `CDKAtomTypeMatcher` throws a `NPE` with that structure due to `IBond.getOrder` being `null` when calling `QueryAtomContainer.getMaximumBondOrder`.

I don't have a concrete idea what should happen in this case, but throwing an NPE is probably not the best outcome... 🤷🏼

comment.body:
See my comment on that PR, unfortunately it's a case of garbage in garbage out... but a better error is "query bond not allowed here or similar".

Since calling the CDKAtomTypeMatcher is optional (and sometimes wrong[1]) this is a tricky one. 

1. the MOL file readers put the correct Hydrogen count using the MDL/Symyx valence model. Applying the CDK model on top of this can change what was provided.

Note V3000 has bond type 9 and 10 for dative and hbonds and this is much more portable.
